sentences.text: In spite of over two decades of intense research , illumination and pose invariance remain prohibitively challenging aspects of face recognition for most practical applications .

The objective of this work is to recognize faces using video sequences both for training and recognition input , in a realistic , unconstrained setup in which lighting , pose and user motion pattern have a wide variability and face images are of low resolution .

In particular there are three areas of novelty : -LRB- i -RRB- we show how a photometric model of image formation can be combined with a statistical model of generic face appearance variation , learnt offline , to generalize in the presence of extreme illumination changes ; -LRB- ii -RRB- we use the smoothness of geodesically local appearance manifold structure and a robust same-identity likelihood to achieve invariance to unseen head poses ; and -LRB- iii -RRB- we introduce an accurate video sequence '' reillumination '' algorithm to achieve robustness to face motion patterns in video .

We describe a fully automatic recognition system based on the proposed method and an extensive evaluation on 171 individuals and over 1300 video sequences with extreme illumination , pose and head motion variation .

On this challenging data set our system consistently demonstrated a nearly perfect recognition rate -LRB- over 99.7 % on all three databases -RRB- , significantly out-performing state-of-the-art commercial software and methods from the literature .

kg2text: The evaluation of the video sequences with extreme illumination, pose and head motion variation is crucial for assessing illumination and pose invariance, which remains challenging for face recognition. The proposed method addresses this challenge by utilizing these video sequences, which include over 1300 video sequences that exhibit significant variations in lighting, pose, and motion. The recognition system, based on this method, evaluates these video sequences to ensure effective performance under varying conditions. Furthermore, the evaluation process involves testing on 171 individuals, demonstrating the system's capability to achieve a nearly perfect recognition rate. This work ultimately aims to recognize faces accurately, despite the complexities introduced by face motion patterns and extreme variations.

The proposed face recognition system has achieved a nearly perfect recognition rate of over 99.7% on all three databases, demonstrating its effectiveness in challenging conditions. This system is designed to recognize faces, addressing the complexities posed by unseen head poses, which remain a broader challenge for face recognition. Additionally, the system incorporates generic face appearance variation, which enhances its ability to recognize faces across diverse conditions. The challenging data set used for evaluation includes over 1300 video sequences that exhibit extreme illumination, pose, and head motion variation, further complicating the recognition task. Despite these challenges, the recognition system out-performs methods from the literature, showcasing its robustness. The geodesically local appearance manifold structure utilized in the system contributes to achieving pose invariance, allowing for accurate recognition even under varying orientations. Overall, this work leverages advanced techniques to ensure reliable face recognition, even in the presence of significant variations in lighting and motion.

The geodesically local appearance manifold structure is a mathematical framework that encompasses faces, which are the biometric features analyzed in video sequences for face recognition. Within this context, pose and head motion variation, as well as unseen head poses, are broader terms that relate to the physical positioning and movement of a person's head, presenting challenges for accurate recognition. Extreme illumination, a broader term for illumination, refers to significant lighting variations that can adversely affect face recognition systems. The photometric model of image formation generalizes in the presence of extreme illumination changes and can be combined with the statistical model of generic face appearance variation, which captures diverse facial appearance variations. Recognition input, a broader term for training, is essential for the recognition system, which outperforms state-of-the-art commercial software. This work, part of over two decades of intense research, aims to enhance face recognition technology by utilizing all three databases, which are organized collections of data that include varying conditions of illumination, pose, and head motion.
